content:
There are a few reasons why Jane chose to leave Rochester rather than stay and work on their differences. Firstly, Jane's strong moral compass and sense of self-respect would not allow her to compromise her values. Rochester wanted her to become his mistress, which goes against her sense of right and wrong. She feels that it is not right to be with a man who is still married, even if his wife is insane and locked up. 

Secondly, Jane realizes that she cannot be truly happy with Rochester if they are not equal partners. She knows that she would always be subordinate to him in their relationship, due to their differences in social class and economic status. She wants to be with someone who values her for who she is and treats her as his equal.

Finally, Jane's decision to leave Rochester is a statement of her newfound identity and independence. Throughout the novel, Jane struggles to establish herself as an individual, apart from the constraints of societal expectations and Rochester's influence on her. By leaving Rochester, she is asserting her independence and choosing to make her own way in the world.

Overall, Jane's decision to leave Rochester may seem dramatic, but it is motivated by her strong sense of morality, desire for equality in their relationship, and newfound sense of identity and independence.
